author: sky.cactus
content: <@543900561460822016> <@425279588009246720> 1559 doesn't preclude legacy transactions from being included, they just don't get the UX benefit of gas estimations or payingmindmum required gas price.

author: sky.cactus
content: I have a PR out against 1559 that makes this change to the spec, so legacy transactions never go away.

author: lightclient
content: In that case, what do you think about having a third tx type in 2718 with the same functionality as the legacy tx that follows the new hashing / signing rules?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!543900561460822016> The tentative plan is to remove all of the new transaction types from 2718 and create a *separate* EIP that defines two new transaction types that are just thin wrappers around legacy transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: Since we aren't immediately deprecating legacy transactions with 2718, we no longer need the new transaction types to be paired with the new wrapper type.

author: sky.cactus
content: Most likely the two would go out in a hard fork together, but it isn't a hard requirement.

author: lightclient
content: So, over the wire are legacy txs still allowed (with legacy encoding)?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes.

author: lightclient
content: Will the new ones follow the new “standard” hashing and signing schemes?

author: sky.cactus
content: The two new ones that I will be proposing will be signature compatible with legacy transactions, but otherwise will follow all of the new rules.

author: lightclient
content: What is the advantage of having them signature compatible of legacy txs will continue to be valid?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!543900561460822016> so someone with a signature from a long time ago can still do a transfer.

author: sky.cactus
content: Or someone with a hardware wallet that cannot be upgraded can still execute transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: We don't want people to end up in a situation where their funds are inaccessible because they are only able to sign legacy transactions.

author: lightclient
content: But I thought you said above that legacy txs will continue to be valid?

author: lightclient
content: In that case, why can’t hardware wallets continue signing and propagating legacy transactions?

author: sky.cactus
content: We would like to eventually like to get rid of legacy transaction wire/block format, but we'll probably *always* retain the legacy transaction signature validity.

author: sky.cactus
content: The two new transaction types I'll propose in a separate EIP will maintain signature compatibility with legacy transactions, but have the new format on the wire and in blocks.

author: lightclient
content: In that case, why continue allowing legacy txs over the wire in the first place?

author: sky.cactus
content:
1. If we *can* split up the EIP we *should* split up the EIP.
2. Transaction propagation is a separate problem from block generation/validation and we cannot change both at once.
3. Transaction hashes will change with the new transaction type, and creates some complexity around the transition.
4. Receipts change, and while we can downgrade the receipt it would be cleaner to introduce new JSON-RPC endpoints for new transaction receipts, and if we do that it takes time for applications to migrate to the new endpoint.

author: sky.cactus
content: Summary: There is a lot of complexity around deprecation, it is easier to handle it separate from the new type EIPs.
